title: How to Grow a Decorative Vegetable Garden

steps.headline: Set out special areas of your garden to display your decorative vegetables.
steps.description: This is not the time to hide the vegetables in the veggie patch! Select eye-catching areas in both the front and backyards to grow your display. A raised bed is usually most suitable, as it sets the vegetables up higher and makes it clear they are part of the garden display.

steps.headline: Select suitable vegetables.
Consider adding in some herbs for colour and contrast around the edges or in between the decorative vegetables.
steps.description: For examples of flowering herbs, see Choose Herb Blossoms for Eating.

steps.headline: Try including edible flowers in your garden.
steps.description: They increase both the colour spectrum and the variety of flavors.

steps.headline: Change the look yearly.
steps.description:
Vegetables tend to be annuals (rhubarb, asparagus, and artichokes are exceptions), so you have an excellent opportunity to vary the vegetable display yearly and to experiment with displays that you like best. In long growing summers, you might even vary the display twice or more during the season. Changing the look can also help with crop rotation, which will help keep your garden and soil healthy. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/43\/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/43\/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Change the look seasonally, too.
steps.description: In some climates, you can plant a succession of cool-season and warm-season crops in the same spot. Planting new plants in succession like this means that you will spend less time looking at empty spaces. It will also improve your overall yields.

steps.headline: Create permanent structure in your garden.
Maintain the garden.
steps.description: Since you wish to look at it as well as cultivate crops, keep it clear of weeds, remove spent foliage and spent crops, keep things pruned neatly, and so on.

steps.headline: Plant vegetables in an attractive layout.
steps.description: You will still need to give everything adequate spacing.

text:
Set out special areas of your garden to display your decorative vegetables. This is not the time to hide the vegetables in the veggie patch! Select eye-catching areas in both the front and backyards to grow your display. A raised bed is usually most suitable, as it sets the vegetables up higher and makes it clear they are part of the garden display. Select suitable vegetables. The success of a decorative vegetable garden will be dependent on the vegetables chosen. Good decorative vegetables include:Globe artichoke - a beautiful large flower, as well as fascinating foliage (see introduction image){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Zucchini / courgette - lovely yellow flowers at the end of each zucchini; train them to grow up bamboo or wooden sticks{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Asparagus - delightful spray-like foliage{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Swiss chard - dark silver and grey leaves and red or yellow stalks{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Endive - lovely curly leaves{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Broccoli - bunches of tiny little flowers, use green, white and light green versions; also brocco-flower and cauliflower varieties can be suitable{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet6.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet6.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Chinese cabbage and oriental greens - differing shades of green and interesting leaf variants{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet7.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet7.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cabbage - just one lovely layer after another! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet8.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet8.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet8.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Rhubarb - brilliant red stalks; try planting pansies, marigolds or similar small flowers underneath for a very interesting contrast; it also has an interesting flower, as seen in this image{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet9.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet9.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet9.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Eggplant / aubergine - wonderful lavender coloured flowers, let alone the interesting fruit{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet10.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet10.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet10.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Peppers / capsicum and chillies - pretty fruits and small flowers, bright leaf colours, variety of fruit colours{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet11.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet11.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet11.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Runner beans and sweet peas - have them clamber over tepee structures, and enjoy not only their productive side but also the lovely flowers and tendrils. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet12.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet12.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet12.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Beets. Some varieties have dark green leaves and dark red stems. Beet greens can also be used as salad greens. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet13.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet13.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet13.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-2Bullet13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Consider adding in some herbs for colour and contrast around the edges or in between the decorative vegetables. For examples of flowering herbs, see Choose Herb Blossoms for Eating. Try including edible flowers in your garden. They increase both the colour spectrum and the variety of flavors. Change the look yearly. Vegetables tend to be annuals (rhubarb, asparagus, and artichokes are exceptions), so you have an excellent opportunity to vary the vegetable display yearly and to experiment with displays that you like best. In long growing summers, you might even vary the display twice or more during the season. Changing the look can also help with crop rotation, which will help keep your garden and soil healthy. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Change the look seasonally, too. In some climates, you can plant a succession of cool-season and warm-season crops in the same spot. Planting new plants in succession like this means that you will spend less time looking at empty spaces. It will also improve your overall yields. Create permanent structure in your garden. Because of the seasonal, temporary nature of most vegetables, you will probably want certain elements to anchor your garden when nothing is growing, or when plants are very small. Here are some elements that can help create permanent structure: Raised beds may be created in a variety of shapes, heights, and patterns. Remember that you will want easy access to the contents of vegetable beds for weeding and harvesting. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Paths, patios, and lawns surrounding the vegetable garden are important elements of negative space. Correctly planned, paths also give you access to your garden without stepping in cultivated areas. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Trellises give your vegetables somewhere to climb, but they probably also persist in your garden during the off-season. Make them attractive, by themselves. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Permanent plantings. These may be trees (fruit trees or ornamental), perennial herbs or vegetables, or simply ornamental perennials. Whatever permanent plantings you choose, try to situate them so that they do not compete too much with your vegetables for light, water, or soil. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Fences, hedges and walls create a perimeter for the garden and they add color and structure. They may also support climbing vines, trellises, or espaliered fruit trees{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Garden statuary, fountains, sundials, and other ornaments are often placed at the center of a formal garden layout. Include one or two to create interest, but don't overdo it. After all, you're growing vegetables, not statuary. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet6.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet6.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Decorative-Vegetable-Garden-Step-7Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Maintain the garden. Since you wish to look at it as well as cultivate crops, keep it clear of weeds, remove spent foliage and spent crops, keep things pruned neatly, and so on. Plant vegetables in an attractive layout. You will still need to give everything adequate spacing.
